div.head: The 1990s: Things could only get better

list.item: Widespread discontent over the poll tax, mad cow disease, economic recession, and the resignation of several ministers finally brought down Mrs Thatcher. She was replaced by John Major, who did at least sign the Maastricht agreement which created the EU ...

For years Belinda had in her window a sign saying “Stop the Poll Tax” and another saying “Free Nelson Mandela”, The first happened in 1992, the second in 1994. The sign saying “This is not here” didnt seem to have any effect.

In academia, everyone was talking about something cool called the World Wide Web: I went to a conference in Warsaw in 1992 at which a French man assured a room full of skeptical hackers from across Europe that the Web would very soon be commercialised. The number of organisations with a Web presence went from a few hundred in 1990 to many thousands in 1999.
On Mayday 1997, after 18 years of Tory misrule, the Labour party (well, Tony Blair) won a General Election with the biggest majority held by any government since 1935.
In November 1994 Eurostar began services through the Channel Tunnel.
The Good Friday Agreement was signed on 10th April 1998, bringing power sharing and at least the semblance of an end to Northern Ireland’s ‘Troubles’.
This was the age of Brit Pop (Radiohead, Oasis, Blur, Pulp, Massive Attack, The Spice Girls ect ect )

div.p:
On the other hand:
At the beginning of the year, we were suckered into joining the first Gulf War.
In July 1998, a little bit of the British Empire called Hong Kong was handed back to the Chinese (it seemed a good idea at the time; it wasn't).
Princess Diana died in a car crash at the end of august 1997, leading to widespread public lamentation and media frenzy.

div.head: 1990: back to the future
div.p: We started the new decade dancing the Lambada at Villa Caroline (those of us who can dance), but within a few days normal service was being resumed in chilly Walton Manor.
In February, there were floods in the University Parks and TEI geeks convened on Oxford for assorted meetings. And Elizabeth got some cool roller skates for her birthday

div.head: Travelling shoes
div.p: In March, I started to build up my carbon foot print. The decade began with TEI meetings across the USA, and conferences across Europe. ...

row.cell: Conference to launch Rutgers-Princeton Database project (later to become CETH)
ACH/ALLC Conference featuring first ever TEI Workshop

div.p: Some say that the true meaning of "TEI" was "Travel Expenses Indefinitely". Certainly this sort of travelling became commonplace over the next few years; during the 90s, there were very, very, few months during which I was not attending a meeting, conference, or workshop somewhere in the US or Europe, or other more exotic locations in the far east. But these were not family occasions, so I won't detail them further.

div.head: Lodgers
div.p: The top floor of no 110 had two bedrooms, one of which we split in two. For most of the year there was a steady flow of student lodgers sleeping there, usually eating dinner with us, and always helping to keep the mortgage under some degree of control.

The lodgers were not university students, but a mixture of A-level re-takers, lost souls striving to scrape through entrance exams, abandoned children of expat poshos from across the world. A few became family friends, but only a few. The Japanese were the most polite and they always came bearing gifts.

div.head: Holidays
div.p: I wasn't the only person travelling in the nineties. There were also holiday expeditions involving current boyfriends, separate expeditions not involving parents, or not involving me, as well as grand community escapades. For example:
In August 1994, we rented a holiday villa in Crete and did summer holiday things like this

Synchronized swimming in the hotel pool, sort of

div.p: In March 1997, we organized a mass expedition to the Trattorio da Olga in Cereglio, just over the hill from Guy's house in Liserna. This was to celebrate Guy's 50th (and mine and Lilette's too), though we returned frequently thereafter, on any excuse.
In July 1998, everyone went to Mauritius, without me (I stayed in Oxford to run the first ever Text Encoding Summer School, closely followed by TALC conference)

And in August 1999, at Allen Renear's invitation, we took Elizabeth on her first transatlantic adventure, via Iceland. We explored Boston, Providence, and Newport RI. We also had a few days cat-sitting in Greenwich Village and visited MOMA.

div.head: Moving on
div.p: In September 1999, Belinda moved out of student accomodation in Forest Fields and into somewhere just a bit posher, with Bob.
Around the same time, Sarah moved out of Forest Fields to London, with Angus.
.... but you'll have to wait for the next decade to see what happened next.
